message: Michele Messina gave us a nice intro to the group and its mission; I'm really looking forward to the more tech-oriented nights personally.
Identify skillsets that translate.
And now it's AG Interactive's Joe Yanoska to talk about moving your business into the mobile space.
Agreed...this should be interesting, though. Admittedly, we have a vested interest.
There is no silver bullet.
Don't forget about QA!
65 million people own smartphones. Had no idea the market was that large.
Start developing API sooner
Question time...
Have to really think carefully about what targets to support.
Starting to explore different strategies for monetizing, doing transactions.
Know your platforms and audience.
Find people in your company who are passionate about tech.
Form strategic committee earlier
Pull things in house earlier
Wireless machine to machine (m2m)
Smart phones are the new designer jeans (or whatever the cool kids used to use as a metric for acceptance).
Find a 12-step program to get off of Blackberry addiction.
Budget for devices and training.
Clever carrier plan swapping and relationship management can help control the costs, as can SIM card swapping.
Yay, shout-outs for Hack Day!  Number of mobile projects is hockey-sticking upward over the past few years: 0, 2, 5, 10!
A solid API is a huge help. Security is important!
Yes, seeing issues with fragmentation in Android devices, capabilities.
Audience suggestion that that is a reason to go with mobile web...
Let your vendor/partner strategy evolve over time.
Carrier data rate limiting/etc not really on AGI's radar yet. Looking to win on coolness, quality of app experience.
Heavy investment in Flash content makes mobile web very tough.
The are BILLIONS of phones! We forget how big a number that really is.
Own your core brand(s) or core offerings. Outsource things that may be more ancillary.
No matter what you do (in house vs. outsource)... Make sure you own the source code!!
Lessons learned...
Devs are mostly specializing, with a few doing more than one platform.  Collaboration is key; many problems are shared across platforms.
Philosophical differences in platforms can make a big difference on learning curves.
We need better batteries, they still suck.
RIM have a hard road ahead.
More powerful smart phones. Richer content with improved resolution.
This time NFC is really for real!
Faster networks, more video. Opportunity for pre- and post-roll ads.
Have not found a really good training course yet. Grass-roots, in-house training  and independent learning seems to be the way to go so far.
Have not done multilingual mobile apps yet; all have been language specific.
Design for Germany and Italy first, since their languages lend themselves to much longer words. This will help with layout problems.
Now to Compuware's Glenn Everitt on "Mobile Trends"...
Android fragmentation. Lots of devices, many suck, some are good.
Low end, cheap devices mostly get ignored except devices like Kindle and Nook.
Offload processing to the cloud. Faster and saves battery.
Mobile ad opportunities. QR codes.
(AR saved us from goofy headgear, but MAI may bring back the fanny pack...)
Digital assistants... Siri http://siri.com/about
In Kenya, 4yo M-Pesa moves 25% of GDP using mobile phones!
Tablets are everywhere!
Location aware apps coming up... Can know when to trigger behavior or messaging in proximity to store, airport, etc.
Smell sensors in phone not far off...
Audience comment: if you're not into mobile, you're going to get crushed. (paraphrased)
Wrapping up, and I only just now see the cookies... Clearly need a location aware app for that!
Cloud storage. Share data between multiple devices.
Mobile is bigger than the Internet: 1.7 billion vs 5 billion!
MS has nice OS, but hard to divert dev resources from existing platforms where they are already successful and making money.
Huge market growth, impressive in down economy.
M2m in health monitoring devices
Slowdown of price decline of apps. Some prices starting to go back up, willingness to pay higher prices for enterprise apps.
Devices a small and can be embedded in many places.
Privacy is going to be a big issue really soon! Phone with gps tracking is like a prisoner with an anklet.
Augmented reality has come a long way, is going to be interesting.
Cloud Dev Day coming up...
Mobile ads will grow to the point of annoyance. Easier to target audience on mobile device than on media buys.
This is all stuff to look at NOW. What's next?
Mobile ambient intelligence. Bring disparate data together with context to make it useful.
Wireless "Body Area Networks"
